metadata.title: Launching | Apple Developer Documentation
metadata.author: Apple Inc.
metadata.summary: Apple Developer Documentation page providing Human Interface Guidelines for app launching experiences. The document covers best practices for launch screens, platform-specific considerations for iOS, iPadOS, tvOS, and visionOS, and guidance on creating streamlined launch experiences that help users start using apps immediately.
metadata.copyright: Copyright 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

content.text: English
Launching
A streamlined launch experience helps people start using your app or game immediately.

content.description: Abstract hero illustration showing layered rectangular shapes representing app screens or windows in a stylized, minimalist design. The shapes are arranged in a cascading pattern suggesting depth and the launch/transition experience. Colors include soft blues, purples, and warm tones with subtle gradients, creating a modern Apple design aesthetic.
content.composition: Centered composition with overlapping rectangular forms creating depth through layering and subtle shadows
content.technicalDetails: Vector illustration with gradient fills and subtle shadows
content.contextualRelevance: Visual representation of the app launching concept, showing layered screens transitioning or loading

content.text: Launching begins when someone opens your app or game, includes an initial download, and ends when the first screen is ready. After launching completes, you might offer an onboarding experience, which can give people a high-level view of your app or game.
Best practices
Launch instantly. People want to start interacting with your app or game right away, and sometimes they don't want to wait more than a couple of seconds.

If the platform requires it, provide a launch screen. In iOS, iPadOS, and tvOS, the system displays your launch screen the moment your app or game starts and quickly replaces it with your first screen, giving people the impression that your experience is fast and responsive. For guidance, see Launch screens. macOS, visionOS, and watchOS don't require launch screens.

emphasis.text: If the platform requires it, provide a launch screen.

content.text: If you need a splash screen, consider displaying it at the beginning of your onboarding flow. A splash screen is a beautiful graphic that succinctly communicates branding and other information you need to provide. If you don't provide an onboarding experience, you might display your splash screen as soon as launching completes.

emphasis.text: If you need a splash screen, consider displaying it at the beginning of your onboarding flow.

content.text: Restore the previous state when your app restarts so people can continue where they left off. Avoid making people retrace steps to reach their previous location in your app or game. Restore granular details of the previous state as much as possible. For example, scroll the view to people's most recent position, and display windows in the same state and location in which people left them.

emphasis.text: Restore the previous state when your app restarts so people can continue where they left off.

content.text: Launch screens
Not applicable for macOS, visionOS, or watchOS.

Downplay the launch experience. A launch screen isn't part of an onboarding experience or a splash screen, and it isn't an opportunity for artistic expression. A launch screen's sole function is to enhance the perception of your experience as quick to launch and immediately ready to use.

Design a launch screen that's nearly identical to the first screen of your app or game. If you include elements that look different when launching completes, people may experience an unpleasant flash between the launch screen and your first screen. If your app or game displays a solid color before transitioning to the first screen, create a launch screen that displays only that solid color. Also make sure that your launch screen matches the device's current orientation and appearance mode.

emphasis.text: Design a launch screen that's nearly identical to the first screen of your app or game.

content.text: Avoid including text on your launch screen, even if your first screen displays text. Because the content in a launch screen doesn't change, any text you display won't be localized.

emphasis.text: Avoid including text on your launch screen, even if your first screen displays text.

content.text: Don't advertise. The launch screen isn't a branding opportunity. Avoid creating a screen that looks like a splash screen or an "About" window, and don't include logos or other branding elements unless they're a fixed part of your app's first screen.
Platform considerations
No additional considerations for macOS or watchOS.
iOS, iPadOS

Launch in the appropriate orientation. If your app or game supports both portrait and landscape modes, launch using the device's current orientation. If your interface only runs in one orientation, launch in that orientation and let people rotate the device if necessary. Ensure a landscape-only interface responds correctly, regardless of whether people enter landscape orientation by rotating the device left or right. For guidance, see Layout.
tvOS

content.label: Note
content.text: Unlike the layered images throughout much of a tvOS app, the launch screen is static.

In a live-viewing app, consider automatically starting playback soon after people start the app. People come to your app to watch TV, so you might want to start playing new or recently viewed live content after a few seconds of inactivity. For guidance, see Live-viewing apps.

emphasis.text: In a live-viewing app, consider automatically starting playback soon after people start the app.

content.text: visionOS

Consider launching in the Shared Space even if your app is fully immersive. Opening a window in the Shared Space lets you provide more context about your app or game while giving it time to load, and it also lets you present a control that people can use to open your fully immersive experience. In general, people appreciate being able to choose when to transition to a Full Space, especially if they're currently running other apps in the Shared Space. For guidance, see Immersive experiences.

emphasis.text: Consider launching in the Shared Space even if your app is fully immersive.

appearanceToggle.description: Theme/appearance mode toggle for the documentation website

pages.pageSummary: Apple Human Interface Guidelines documentation page for 'Launching'. Provides comprehensive guidance on creating streamlined app launch experiences across all Apple platforms (iOS, iPadOS, macOS, tvOS, visionOS, watchOS). Covers best practices for instant launching, launch screens vs splash screens, state restoration, and platform-specific considerations including orientation handling on iOS/iPadOS, static launch screens on tvOS, and Shared Space launching on visionOS.

crossPageElements.runningFooters: Apple Developer footer with platform links, tools, resources, support, and legal information

sections.title: Introduction
sections.summary: Defines launching as the experience from app open through first screen ready, introduces onboarding as a follow-up experience.

sections.title: Best practices
sections.summary: Four key best practices: launch instantly, provide platform-required launch screens, consider splash screens for onboarding, and restore previous state on restart.

sections.title: Launch screens
sections.summary: Guidance specific to launch screens (not applicable to macOS, visionOS, watchOS): downplay the experience, match first screen design, avoid text, and don't advertise.

sections.title: Platform considerations

subsections.title: iOS, iPadOS
subsections.summary: Launch in appropriate orientation based on device state and supported orientations.

subsections.title: tvOS
subsections.summary: Launch screens are static (unlike layered images); live-viewing apps should consider auto-playing content.

subsections.title: visionOS
subsections.summary: Consider launching in Shared Space even for fully immersive apps to provide context and user control over transition to Full Space.

sections.summary: Platform-specific launching guidance for iOS/iPadOS (orientation), tvOS (static screens, auto-play), and visionOS (Shared Space launching).

sections.title: Resources

subsections.title: Related
subsections.summary: Links to Onboarding and Loading documentation.

subsections.title: Developer documentation
subsections.summary: Links to Xcode and UIKit documentation for launch screen implementation.

subsections.title: Videos
subsections.summary: Two WWDC videos: 'Optimizing App Launch' and 'Love at First Launch'.

sections.summary: Collection of related resources including HIG documentation, developer documentation for Xcode and UIKit, and WWDC session videos.

sections.title: Change log
sections.summary: Document revision history: June 2024 added splash screen guidance, June 2023 added visionOS guidance.

semanticStructure.documentFlow: The document follows Apple's standard HIG documentation structure: introduction with hero image and platform support indicators, followed by best practices as general guidance, then specific launch screen guidelines, platform-specific considerations organized by operating system, resource links for further learning, and finally a change log showing document revisions.

keyTerms.definition: The experience that begins when someone opens your app or game, includes an initial download, and ends when the first screen is ready.

A static screen displayed by the system the moment an app starts, quickly replaced by the first screen to give the impression of fast and responsive experience. Required on iOS, iPadOS, and tvOS; not required on macOS, visionOS, or watchOS.
A beautiful graphic that succinctly communicates branding and other information, typically displayed at the beginning of an onboarding flow or after launching completes.
An experience offered after launching completes that gives people a high-level view of the app or game.
A visionOS environment where multiple apps can run together, as opposed to a Full Space which is fully immersive.
A visionOS environment for fully immersive experiences where only one app runs.
Dynamic, parallax-enabled images used throughout tvOS apps, in contrast to static launch screens.
The practice of restoring the previous app state when restarting so users can continue where they left off.

keyFindings: Launch screens serve only to enhance perception of quick launch; they are not for branding, artistic expression, or onboarding.
Launch screens should be nearly identical to the first screen of the app to avoid visual flash during transition.
Text should be avoided on launch screens because launch screen content cannot be localized.
Apps should restore granular previous state details including scroll position and window states.
On visionOS, even fully immersive apps should consider launching in Shared Space to give users control over when to enter Full Space.
On tvOS, launch screens are static unlike the layered images used elsewhere in the app.
Live-viewing tvOS apps should consider auto-starting playback after a few seconds of inactivity.
iOS/iPadOS apps should launch in the device's current orientation when supporting both portrait and landscape.
Splash screens (for branding) are distinct from launch screens and should be shown during onboarding, not as the launch screen itself.

relatedAPIs: Responding to the launch of your app (UIKit)

designDecisions.decision: Launch screen design should match first screen
designDecisions.rationale: Prevents unpleasant visual flash between launch screen and first screen
Launch screen content cannot be changed or localized

designDecisions.decision: No branding elements on launch screens
designDecisions.rationale: Launch screens are not branding opportunities; branding belongs in splash screens during onboarding

designDecisions.decision: Consider Shared Space launch for visionOS immersive apps
designDecisions.rationale: Allows loading time, provides context, and lets users choose when to enter Full Space

designDecisions.decision: Auto-play content on tvOS live-viewing apps
designDecisions.rationale: Users come to watch TV; starting playback matches user intent

verbatimTextContent.subtitle: A streamlined launch experience helps people start using your app or game immediately.
verbatimTextContent.introductionParagraph: Launching begins when someone opens your app or game, includes an initial download, and ends when the first screen is ready. After launching completes, you might offer an onboarding experience, which can give people a high-level view of your app or game.

practices.fullText: Launch instantly. People want to start interacting with your app or game right away, and sometimes they don't want to wait more than a couple of seconds.

practices.leadSentence: If the platform requires it, provide a launch screen.
practices.fullText: If the platform requires it, provide a launch screen. In iOS, iPadOS, and tvOS, the system displays your launch screen the moment your app or game starts and quickly replaces it with your first screen, giving people the impression that your experience is fast and responsive. For guidance, see Launch screens. macOS, visionOS, and watchOS don't require launch screens.

practices.leadSentence: If you need a splash screen, consider displaying it at the beginning of your onboarding flow.
practices.fullText: If you need a splash screen, consider displaying it at the beginning of your onboarding flow. A splash screen is a beautiful graphic that succinctly communicates branding and other information you need to provide. If you don't provide an onboarding experience, you might display your splash screen as soon as launching completes.

practices.leadSentence: Restore the previous state when your app restarts so people can continue where they left off.
practices.fullText: Restore the previous state when your app restarts so people can continue where they left off. Avoid making people retrace steps to reach their previous location in your app or game. Restore granular details of the previous state as much as possible. For example, scroll the view to people's most recent position, and display windows in the same state and location in which people left them.

guidelines.fullText: Downplay the launch experience. A launch screen isn't part of an onboarding experience or a splash screen, and it isn't an opportunity for artistic expression. A launch screen's sole function is to enhance the perception of your experience as quick to launch and immediately ready to use.

guidelines.fullText: Design a launch screen that's nearly identical to the first screen of your app or game. If you include elements that look different when launching completes, people may experience an unpleasant flash between the launch screen and your first screen. If your app or game displays a solid color before transitioning to the first screen, create a launch screen that displays only that solid color. Also make sure that your launch screen matches the device's current orientation and appearance mode.

guidelines.leadSentence: Avoid including text on your launch screen, even if your first screen displays text.
guidelines.fullText: Avoid including text on your launch screen, even if your first screen displays text. Because the content in a launch screen doesn't change, any text you display won't be localized.

Don't advertise. The launch screen isn't a branding opportunity. Avoid creating a screen that looks like a splash screen or an "About" window, and don't include logos or other branding elements unless they're a fixed part of your app's first screen.

platformConsiderationsSection.generalNote: No additional considerations for macOS or watchOS.

content.fullText: Launch in the appropriate orientation. If your app or game supports both portrait and landscape modes, launch using the device's current orientation. If your interface only runs in one orientation, launch in that orientation and let people rotate the device if necessary. Ensure a landscape-only interface responds correctly, regardless of whether people enter landscape orientation by rotating the device left or right. For guidance, see Layout.

note.text: Unlike the layered images throughout much of a tvOS app, the launch screen is static.

content.leadSentence: In a live-viewing app, consider automatically starting playback soon after people start the app.
content.fullText: In a live-viewing app, consider automatically starting playback soon after people start the app. People come to your app to watch TV, so you might want to start playing new or recently viewed live content after a few seconds of inactivity. For guidance, see Live-viewing apps.

content.leadSentence: Consider launching in the Shared Space even if your app is fully immersive.
content.fullText: Consider launching in the Shared Space even if your app is fully immersive. Opening a window in the Shared Space lets you provide more context about your app or game while giving it time to load, and it also lets you present a control that people can use to open your fully immersive experience. In general, people appreciate being able to choose when to transition to a Full Space, especially if they're currently running other apps in the Shared Space.
